dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eLightweight single-thread asynchronous IO.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003ePure python, no additional library required.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eProxy client/server for TCP/UDP.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eSchedule (load balance) among remote servers.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eIncoming traffic auto-detect.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eTunnel/jump/backward-jump support.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eUnix domain socket support.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eHTTP v2, HTTP v3 (QUIC)\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eUser/password authentication support.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eFilter/block hostname by regex patterns.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eSSL/TLS client/server support.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eShadowsocks OTA (\u003ca href=\"https://shadowsocks.org/en/spec/one-time-auth.html\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eOne-Time-Auth\u003c/a\u003e), SSR plugins.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eStatistics by bandwidth and traffic.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003ePAC support for javascript configuration.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eIptables/Pf NAT redirect packet tunnel.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eSystem proxy auto-setting support.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eClient/Server API provided.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003ca dir=\"auto\"\u003e2\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/tbody\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003cem\u003epproxy\u003c/em\u003e ciphers have pure python implementations. Program will switch to C cipher if there is C implementation available within \u003ca href=\"https://pycryptodome.readthedocs.io/en/latest/src/introduction.html\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003epycryptodome\u003c/a\u003e. Otherwise, use pure python cipher.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eAEAD ciphers use additional payload after each packet. The underlying protocol is different. Specifications: \u003ca href=\"http://shadowsocks.org/en/spec/AEAD-Ciphers.html\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eAEAD\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eSome pure python ciphers (aes-256-cfb1-py) is quite slow, and is not recommended to use without PyPy speedup. Try install \u003ca href=\"https://pycryptodome.readthedocs.io/en/latest/src/introduction.html\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003epycryptodome\u003c/a\u003e and use C version cipher instead.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eTo enable OTA encryption with shadowsocks, add '!' immediately after cipher name.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003enetloc\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eIt can be \"hostname:port\" or \"/unix_domain_socket\". If the hostname is empty, server will listen on all interfaces.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eValid netloc: localhost:8080, 0.0.0.0:8123, /tmp/domain_socket, :8123\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003elocalbind\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eIt can be \"@in\" or @ipv4_address or @ipv6_address\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eValid localbind: @in, @192.168.1.15, @::1\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eplugins\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eIt can be multiple plugins joined by \",\". Supported plugins: plain, origin, http_simple, tls1.2_ticket_auth, verify_simple, verify_deflate\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eValid plugins: /,tls1.2_ticket_auth,verify_simple\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003erules\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eThe filename that contains regex rules\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eauth\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eThe username, colon ':', and the password\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eURIs can be joined by \"__\" to indicate tunneling by jump. For example, ss://1.2.3.4:1324__\u003ca href=\"http://4.5.6.7:4321\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003ehttp://4.5.6.7:4321\u003c/a\u003e make remote connection to the first shadowsocks proxy server, and then jump to the second http proxy server.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ca name=\"user-content-client-api\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"markdown-heading\" dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ch2 tabindex=\"-1\" dir=\"auto\" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=\"import asyncio, pproxy\n\nasync def test_tcp(proxy_uri):\n    conn = pproxy.Connection(proxy_uri)\n    reader, writer = await conn.tcp_connect('google.com', 80)\n    writer.write(b'GET / HTTP/1.1\\r\\n\\r\\n')\n    data = await reader.read(1024*16)\n    print(data.decode())\n\nasyncio.run(test_tcp('ss://aes-256-cfb:password@remote_host:remote_port'))\"\u003e\u003cpre\u003eimport asyncio, pproxy\n\nasync def test_tcp(proxy_uri):\n    conn = = await reader.read(1024*16)\n    print(data.decode())\n\nasyncio.run(test_tcp('ss://aes-256-cfb:password@remote_host:remote_port'))\u003c/pre\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eUDP Client await answer\n    print(answer.result())\n\nasyncio.run(test_udp('ss://chacha20:password@remote_host:remote_port'))\"\u003e\u003cpre\u003eimport asyncio, pproxy\n\nasync def test_udp(proxy_uri):\n asyncio\nimport pproxy\n\nserver = pproxy.Server('ss://0.0.0.0:1234')\nremote = pproxy.Connection('ss://1.2.3.4:5678')\nargs = dict( rserver = [remote],\n             verbose = print )\n\nloop = asyncio.get_event_loop()\nhandler = loop.run_until_complete(server.start_server(args))\ntry:\n    loop.run_forever()\nexcept KeyboardInterrupt:\n    print('exit!')\n\nhandler.close()\nloop.run_until_complete(handler.wait_closed())\nloop.run_until_complete(loop.shutdown_asyncgens())\nloop.close()\"\u003e\u003cpre\u003eimport asyncio\nimport pproxy\n\nserver = pproxy.Server('ss://0.0.0.0:1234')\nremote = pproxy.Connection('ss://1.2.3.4:5678')\nargs = dict( rserver = [remote],\n             verbose = print )\n\nloop = asyncio.get_event_loop()\nhandler = loop.run_until_complete(server.start_server(args))\ntry:\n    loop.run_forever()\nexcept KeyboardInterrupt:\n    print('exit!')\n\nhandler.close()\nloop.run_until_complete(handler.wait_closed())\nloop.run_until_complete(loop.shutdown_asyncgens())\nloop.close()\u003c/pre\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003ca class=\"pl-cce\"\u003e\\.\u003c/span\u003enet\n(?:.+\u003cspan class=\"pl-cce\"\u003e\\.\u003c/span\u003e)?ggpht\u003cspan class=\"pl-cce\"\u003e\\.\u003c/span\u003ecom\n(?:.+\u003cspan class=\"pl-cce\"\u003e\\.\u003c/span\u003egl\n(?:.+\u003cspan class=\"pl-cce\"\u003e\\.\u003c/span\u003e)?youtu\u003cspan class=\"pl-cce\"\u003e\\.\u003c/span\u003ebe\n(?:.+\u003cspan class=\"pl-cce\"\u003e\\.\u003c/span\u003e)?google\u003cspan class=\"pl-cce\"\u003e\\.\u003c/span\u003e.+\u003c/pre\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eThen start \u003cem\u003epproxy\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"highlight highlight-text-restructuredtext notranslate position-relative overflow-auto\" dir=\"auto\" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=\"$ pproxy -r http://aa.bb.cc.dd:8080?rules -vv\nServing on :8080 by http,socks4,socks5\nhttp ::1:57768 -\u0026gt; http aa.bb.cc.dd:8080 -\u0026gt; www.googleapis.com:443\nhttp ::1:57772 -\u0026gt; www.yahoo.com:80\nsocks4 ::1:57770 -\u0026gt; http aa.bb.cc.dd:8080 -\u0026gt; www.youtube.com:443\"\u003e\u003cpre\u003e$ pproxy -r http://aa.bb.cc.dd:8080?rules -vv\nServing on :8080 by http,socks4,socks5\nhttp ::1:57768 -\u0026gt; http aa.bb.cc.dd:8080 -\u0026gt; www.googleapis.com:443\nhttp ::1:57772 -\u0026gt; www.yahoo.com:80\nsocks4 ::1:57770 -\u0026gt; http aa.bb.cc.dd:8080 -\u0026gt; www.youtube.com:443\u003c/pre\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003cem\u003epproxy\u003c/em\u003e will serve incoming traffic by http/socks4/socks5 auto-detect protocol, redirect all google traffic to http proxy aa.bb.cc.dd:8080, and visit all other traffic directly from local.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eUse cipher\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eAdd cipher encryption to make sure data can't be intercepted. Run \u003cem\u003epproxy\u003c/em\u003e locally as:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"highlight highlight-text-restructuredtext notranslate position-relative overflow-auto\" dir=\"auto\" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=\"$ pproxy -l ss://:8888 -r ss://chacha20:cipher_key@aa.bb.cc.dd:12345 -vv\"\u003e\u003cpre\u003e$ pproxy -l ss://:8888 -r ss://chacha20:cipher_key@aa.bb.cc.dd:12345 -vv\u003c/pre\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eNext, run pproxy.py remotely on server \"aa.bb.cc.dd\". The base64 encoded string of \"chacha20:cipher_key\" is also supported:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"highlight highlight-text-restructuredtext notranslate position-relative overflow-auto\" dir=\"auto\" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=\"$ pproxy -l ss://chacha20:cipher_key@:12345\"\u003e\u003cpre\u003e$ pproxy -l ss://chacha20:cipher_key@:12345\u003c/pre\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eThe same as:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"highlight highlight-text-restructuredtext notranslate position-relative overflow-auto\" dir=\"auto\" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=\"$ pproxy -l ss://Y2hhY2hhMjA6Y2lwaGVyX2tleQ==@:12345\"\u003e\u003cpre\u003e$ pproxy -l ss://Y2hhY2hhMjA6Y2lwaGVyX2tleQ==@:12345\u003c/pre\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eThe traffic between local and aa.bb.cc.dd is encrypted by stream cipher Chacha20 with secret key \"cipher_key\".\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eUnix domain socket\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eA more complex example:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"highlight highlight-text-restructuredtext notranslate position-relative overflow-auto\" dir=\"auto\" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=\"$ pproxy -l ss://salsa20!:complex_cipher_key@/tmp/pproxy_socket -r http+ssl://domain1.com:443#username:password\"\u003e\u003cpre\u003e$ pproxy -l ss://salsa20!:complex_cipher_key@/tmp/pproxy_socket -r http+ssl://domain1.com:443#username:password\u003c/pre\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003cem\u003epproxy\u003c/em\u003e listen on the unix domain socket \"/tmp/pproxy_socket\" with cipher \"salsa20\" and key \"complex_cipher_key\". OTA packet protocol is enabled by adding ! after cipher name. The traffic is tunneled to remote https proxy with simple http authentication.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eSSL/TLS server\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eIf you want to listen in SSL/TLS, you must specify ssl certificate and private key files by parameter \"--ssl\":\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"highlight highlight-text-restructuredtext notranslate position-relative overflow-auto\" dir=\"auto\" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=\"$ pproxy -l http+ssl://0.0.0.0:443 -l http://0.0.0.0:80 --ssl server.crt,server.key --pac /autopac\"\u003e\u003cpre\u003e$ pproxy -l http+ssl://0.0.0.0:443 -l http://0.0.0.0:80 --ssl server.crt,server.key --pac /autopac\u003c/pre\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003cem\u003epproxy\u003c/em\u003e listen on both 80 HTTP and 443 HTTPS ports, use the specified SSL/TLS certificate and private key files. The \"--pac\" enable PAC feature, so you can put \"\u003ca href=\"https://yourdomain.com/autopac\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003ehttps://yourdomain.com/autopac\u003c/a\u003e\" path in your device's auto-configure url.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eSimple guide for generating self-signed ssl certificates:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"highlight highlight-text-restructuredtext notranslate position-relative overflow-auto\" dir=\"auto\" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=\"$ openssl genrsa -des3 -out server.key 1024\n$ openssl req -new -key server.key -out server.csr\n$ cp server.key server.key.org\n$ openssl rsa -in server.key.org -out server.key\n$ openssl x509 -req -days 365 -in server.csr -signkey server.key -out server.crt\"\u003e\u003cpre\u003e$ openssl genrsa -des3 -out server.key 1024\n$ openssl req -new -key server.key -out server.csr\n$ cp server.key server.key.org\n$ openssl rsa -in server.key.org -out server.key\n$ openssl x509 -req -days 365 -in server.csr -signkey server.key -out server.crt\u003c/pre\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eSSR plugins\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eShadowsocksR example with plugin \"tls1.2_ticket_auth\" to emulate common tls traffic:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"highlight highlight-text-restructuredtext notranslate position-relative overflow-auto\" dir=\"auto\" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=\"$ pproxy -l ssr://chacha20:mypass@0.0.0.0:443/,tls1.2_ticket_auth,verify_simple\"\u003e\u003cpre\u003e$ pproxy -l ssr://chacha20:mypass@0.0.0.0:443/,tls1.2_ticket_auth,verify_simple\u003c/pre\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eLocal bind ip\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eIf you want to route the traffic by different local bind, use the @localbind URI syntax. For example, server has three ip interfaces: 192.168.1.15, 111.0.0.1, 112.0.0.1. You want to route traffic matched by \"rule1\" to 111.0.0.2 and traffic matched by \"rule2\" to 222.0.0.2, and the remaining traffic directly:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"highlight highlight-text-restructuredtext notranslate position-relative overflow-auto\" dir=\"auto\" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=\"$ pproxy -l ss://:8000/@in -r ss://111.0.0.2:8000/@111.0.0.1?rule1 -r ss://222.0.0.2:8000/@222.0.0.1?rule2\"\u003e\u003cpre\u003e$ pproxy -l ss://:8000/@in -r ss://111.0.0.2:8000/@111.0.0.1?rule1 -r ss://222.0.0.2:8000/@222.0.0.1?rule2\u003c/pre\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eRedirect/Pf protocol\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eIPTable NAT redirect example (Ubuntu):\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"highlight highlight-text-restructuredtext notranslate position-relative overflow-auto\" dir=\"auto\" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=\"$ sudo iptables -t nat -A OUTPUT -p tcp --dport 80 -j REDIRECT --to-ports 5555\n$ pproxy -l redir://:5555 -r http://remote_http_server:3128 -vv\"\u003e\u003cpre\u003e$ sudo iptables -t nat -A OUTPUT -p tcp --dport 80 -j REDIRECT --to-ports 5555\n$ pproxy -l redir://:5555 -r http://remote_http_server:3128 -vv\u003c/pre\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eThe above example illustrates how to redirect all local output tcp traffic with destination port 80 to localhost port 5555 listened by \u003cstrong\u003epproxy\u003c/strong\u003e, and then tunnel the traffic to remote http proxy.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003ePF redirect example (MacOS):\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"highlight highlight-text-restructuredtext notranslate position-relative overflow-auto\" dir=\"auto\" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=\"$ sudo pfctl -ef /dev/stdin\nrdr pass on lo0 inet proto tcp from any to any port 80 -\u0026gt; 127.0.0.1 port 8080\npass out on en0 route-to lo0 inet proto tcp from any to any port 80 keep state\n^D\n$ sudo pproxy -l pf://:8080 -r socks5://remote_socks5_server:1324 -vv\"\u003e\u003cpre\u003e$ sudo pfctl -ef /dev/stdin\nrdr pass on lo0 inet proto tcp from any to any port 80 -\u0026gt; 127.0.0.1 port 8080\npass out on en0 route-to lo0 inet proto tcp from any to any port 80 keep state\n^D\n$ sudo pproxy -l pf://:8080 -r socks5://remote_socks5_server:1324 -vv\u003c/pre\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eMake sure \u003cstrong\u003epproxy\u003c/strong\u003e runs in root mode (sudo), otherwise it cannot redirect pf packet.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eMultiple jumps example\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"highlight highlight-text-restructuredtext notranslate position-relative overflow-auto\" dir=\"auto\" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=\"$ pproxy -r http://server1__ss://server2__socks://server3\"\u003e\u003cpre\u003e$ pproxy -r http://server1__ss://server2__socks://server3\u003c/pre\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003cem\u003epproxy\u003c/em\u003e will connect to server1 first, tell server1 connect to server2, and tell server2 connect to server3, and make real traffic by server3.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eRaw connection tunnel\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eTCP raw connection tunnel example:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"highlight highlight-text-restructuredtext notranslate position-relative overflow-auto\" dir=\"auto\" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=\"$ pproxy -l tunnel{google.com}://:80\n$ curl -H \u0026quot;Host: google.com\u0026quot; http://localhost\"\u003e\u003cpre\u003e$ pproxy -l tunnel{google.com}://:80\n$ curl -H \"Host: google.com\" http://localhost\u003c/pre\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eUDP dns tunnel example:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"highlight highlight-text-restructuredtext notranslate position-relative overflow-auto\" dir=\"auto\" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=\"$ pproxy -ul tunnel{8.8.8.8}://:53\n$ nslookup google.com localhost\"\u003e\u003cpre\u003e$ pproxy -ul tunnel{8.8.8.8}://:53\n$ nslookup google.com localhost\u003c/pre\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eUDP more complicated example\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eRun the shadowsocks udp proxy on remote machine:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"highlight highlight-text-restructuredtext notranslate position-relative overflow-auto\" dir=\"auto\" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=\"$ pproxy -ul ss://remote_server:13245\"\u003e\u003cpre\u003e$ pproxy -ul ss://remote_server:13245\u003c/pre\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eRun the commands on local machine:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"highlight highlight-text-restructuredtext notranslate position-relative overflow-auto\" dir=\"auto\" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=\"$ pproxy -ul tunnel{8.8.8.8}://:53 -ur ss://remote_server:13245 -vv\nUDP tunnel 127.0.0.1:60573 -\u0026gt; ss remote_server:13245 -\u0026gt; 8.8.8.8:53\nUDP tunnel 127.0.0.1:60574 -\u0026gt; ss remote_server:13245 -\u0026gt; 8.8.8.8:53\n...\n$ nslookup google.com localhost\"\u003e\u003cpre\u003e$ pproxy -ul tunnel{8.8.8.8}://:53 -ur ss://remote_server:13245 -vv\nUDP tunnel 127.0.0.1:60573 -\u0026gt; ss remote_server:13245 -\u0026gt; 8.8.8.8:53\nUDP tunnel 127.0.0.1:60574 -\u0026gt; ss remote_server:13245 -\u0026gt; 8.8.8.8:53\n\u003cspan class=\"pl-mh\"\u003e...\u003c/span\u003e\n$ nslookup google.com localhost\u003c/pre\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eLoad balance example\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eSpecify multiple -r server, and a scheduling algorithm (rr = round_robin, rc = random_choice, lc = least_connection):\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"highlight highlight-text-restructuredtext notranslate position-relative overflow-auto\" dir=\"auto\" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=\"$ pproxy -r http://server1 -r ss://server2 -r socks5://server3 -s rr -vv\nhttp ::1:42356 -\u0026gt; http server1 -\u0026gt; google.com:443\nhttp ::1:42357 -\u0026gt; ss server2 -\u0026gt; google.com:443\nhttp ::1:42358 -\u0026gt; socks5 server3 -\u0026gt; google.com:443\nhttp ::1:42359 -\u0026gt; http server1 -\u0026gt; google.com:443\n...\n$ pproxy -ul tunnel://:53 -ur tunnel://8.8.8.8:53 -ur tunnel://8.8.4.4:53 -s rc -vv\nUDP tunnel ::1:35378 -\u0026gt; tunnel 8.8.8.8:53\nUDP tunnel ::1:35378 -\u0026gt; tunnel 8.8.4.4:53\n...\"\u003e\u003cpre\u003e$ pproxy -r http://server1 -r ss://server2 -r socks5://server3 -s rr -vv\nhttp ::1:42356 -\u0026gt; http server1 -\u0026gt; google.com:443\nhttp ::1:42357 -\u0026gt; ss server2 -\u0026gt; google.com:443\nhttp ::1:42358 -\u0026gt; socks5 server3 -\u0026gt; google.com:443\nhttp ::1:42359 -\u0026gt; http server1 -\u0026gt; google.com:443\n\u003cspan class=\"pl-mh\"\u003e...\u003c/span\u003e\n$ pproxy -ul tunnel://:53 -ur tunnel://8.8.8.8:53 -ur tunnel://8.8.4.4:53 -s rc -vv\nUDP tunnel ::1:35378 -\u0026gt; tunnel 8.8.8.8:53\nUDP tunnel ::1:35378 -\u0026gt; tunnel 8.8.4.4:53\n\u003cspan class=\"pl-mh\"\u003e...\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/pre\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eWebSocket example\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eWebSocket protocol is similar to Tunnel protocol. It is raw and doesn't support any proxy function. It can connect to other proxy like Tunnel protocol.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eFirst run pproxy on remote machine:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"highlight highlight-text-restructuredtext notranslate position-relative overflow-auto\" dir=\"auto\" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=\"$ pproxy -l ws://:80 -r tunnel:///tmp/myproxy -v\n$ pproxy -l ss://chacha20:abc@/tmp/myproxy -v\"\u003e\u003cpre\u003e$ pproxy -l ws://:80 -r tunnel:///tmp/myproxy -v\n$ pproxy -l ss://chacha20:abc@/tmp/myproxy -v\u003c/pre\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eRun pproxy on local machine:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"highlight highlight-text-restructuredtext notranslate position-relative overflow-auto\" dir=\"auto\" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=\"$ pproxy -l tunnel://:1234 -r ws://remote_ip:80 -vv\"\u003e\u003cpre\u003e$ pproxy -l tunnel://:1234 -r ws://remote_ip:80 -vv\u003c/pre\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eThen port :1234 on local machine is connected to the /tmp/myproxy on remote machine by WebSocket tunnel. You can specify any proxy protocol details on /tmp/myproxy.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eIt is a good practice to use some CDN in the middle of local/remote machines. CDN with WebSocket support can hide remote machine's real IP from public.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eBackward proxy\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eSometimes, the proxy server hides behind an NAT router and doesn't have a public ip. The client side has a public ip \"client_ip\". Backward proxy feature enables the server to connect backward to client and wait for proxy requests.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eRun \u003cstrong\u003epproxy\u003c/strong\u003e client as follows:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"highlight highlight-text-restructuredtext notranslate position-relative overflow-auto\" dir=\"auto\" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=\"$ pproxy -l http://:8080 -r http+in://:8081 -v\"\u003e\u003cpre\u003e$ pproxy -l http://:8080 -r http+in://:8081 -v\u003c/pre\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eRun \u003cstrong\u003epproxy\u003c/strong\u003e server as follows:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"highlight highlight-text-restructuredtext notranslate position-relative overflow-auto\" dir=\"auto\" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=\"$ pproxy -l http+in://client_ip:8081\"\u003e\u003cpre\u003e$ pproxy -l http+in://client_ip:8081\u003c/pre\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eServer connects to client_ip:8081 and waits for client proxy requests. The protocol http specified is just an example. It can be any protocol and cipher \u003cstrong\u003epproxy\u003c/strong\u003e supports. The scheme \"\u003cstrong\u003ein\u003c/strong\u003e\" should exist in URI to inform \u003cstrong\u003epproxy\u003c/strong\u003e that it is a backward proxy.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"highlight highlight-text-restructuredtext notranslate position-relative overflow-auto\" dir=\"auto\" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=\"$ pproxy -l http+in://jumpserver__http://client_ip:8081\"\u003e\u003cpre\u003e$ pproxy -l http+in://jumpserver__http://client_ip:8081\u003c/pre\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eIt is a complicated example. Server connects to client_ip:8081 by jump \u003ca href=\"http://jumpserver\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003ehttp://jumpserver\u003c/a\u003e. The backward proxy works through jumps.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eSSH client tunnel\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eSSH client tunnel support is enabled by installing additional library \u003ca href=\"https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003easyncssh\u003c/a\u003e. After \"pip3 install asyncssh\", you can specify \"\u003cstrong\u003essh\u003c/strong\u003e\" as scheme to proxy via ssh client tunnel.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"highlight highlight-text-restructuredtext notranslate position-relative overflow-auto\" dir=\"auto\" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=\"$ pproxy -l http://:8080 -r ssh://remote_server.com/#login:password\"\u003e\u003cpre\u003e$ pproxy -l http://:8080 -r ssh://remote_server.com/#login:password\u003c/pre\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eIf a client private key is used to authenticate, put double colon \"::\" between login and private key path.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"highlight highlight-text-restructuredtext notranslate position-relative overflow-auto\" dir=\"auto\" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=\"$ pproxy -l http://:8080 -r ssh://remote_server.com/#login::private_key_path\"\u003e\u003cpre\u003e$ pproxy -l http://:8080 -r ssh://remote_server.com/#login::private_key_path\u003c/pre\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eSSH connection known_hosts feature is disabled by default.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eSSH jump\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eSSH jump is supported by using \"__\" concatenation\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"highlight highlight-text-restructuredtext notranslate position-relative overflow-auto\" dir=\"auto\" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=\"$ pproxy -r ssh://server1__ssh://server2__ssh://server3\"\u003e\u003cpre\u003e$ pproxy -r ssh://server1__ssh://server2__ssh://server3\u003c/pre\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eFirst connection to server1 is made. Second, ssh connection to server2 is made from server1. Finally, connect to server3, and use server3 for proxying traffic.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eSSH remote forward\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"highlight highlight-text-restructuredtext notranslate position-relative overflow-auto\" dir=\"auto\" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=\"$ pproxy -l ssh://server__tunnel://0.0.0.0:1234 -r tunnel://127.0.0.1:1234\"\u003e\u003cpre\u003e$ pproxy -l ssh://server__tunnel://0.0.0.0:1234 -r tunnel://127.0.0.1:1234\u003c/pre\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eTCP :1234 on remote server is forwarded to 127.0.0.1:1234 on local server\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"highlight highlight-text-restructuredtext notranslate position-relative overflow-auto\" dir=\"auto\" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=\"$ pproxy -l ssh://server1__ssh://server2__ss://0.0.0.0:1234 -r ss://server3:1234\"\u003e\u003cpre\u003e$ pproxy -l ssh://server1__ssh://server2__ss://0.0.0.0:1234 -r ss://server3:1234\u003c/pre\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eIt is a complicated example. SSH server2 is jumped from SSH server1, and ss://0.0.0.0:1234 on server2 is listened. Traffic is forwarded to ss://server3:1234.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eTrojan protocol example\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eNormally trojan:// should be used together with ssl://. You should specify the SSL crt/key file for ssl usage. A typical trojan server would be:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"highlight highlight-text-restructuredtext notranslate position-relative overflow-auto\" dir=\"auto\" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=\"$ pproxy --ssl ssl.crt,ssl.key -l trojan+tunnel{localhost:80}+ssl://:443#yourpassword -vv\"\u003e\u003cpre\u003e$ pproxy --ssl ssl.crt,ssl.key -l trojan+tunnel{localhost:80}+ssl://:443#yourpassword -vv\u003c/pre\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eIf trojan password doesn't match, the tunnal{localhost:80} will be switched to. It looks exactly the same as a common HTTPS website.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eQUIC protocol example\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eQUIC is a UDP stream protocol used in HTTP/3. Library \u003cstrong\u003eaioquic\u003c/strong\u003e is required if you want to proxy via QUIC.\nQUIC is listened on UDP port, but can handle TCP or UDP traffic. If you want to handle TCP traffic, you should use \"-l quic+http\" instead of \"-ul quic+http\".\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"highlight highlight-text-restructuredtext notranslate position-relative overflow-auto\" dir=\"auto\" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=\"$ pip3 install aioquic\n$ pproxy --ssl ssl.crt,ssl.key -l quic+http://:1234\"\u003e\u003cpre\u003e$ pip3 install aioquic\n$ pproxy --ssl ssl.crt,ssl.key -l quic+http://:1234\u003c/pre\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eOn the client:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cblockquote\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e$ pproxy -r quic+http://server:1234\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/blockquote\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eQUIC protocol can transfer a lot of TCP streams on one single UDP stream. If the connection number is hugh, QUIC can benefit by reducing TCP handshake time.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eVPN Server Example\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eYou can run VPN server simply by installing pvpn (python vpn), a lightweight VPN server with pproxy tunnel feature.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"highlight highlight-text-restructuredtext notranslate position-relative overflow-auto\" dir=\"auto\" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=\"$ pip3 install pvpn\nSuccessfully installed pvpn-0.2.1\n$ pvpn -wg 9999 -r http://remote_server:remote_port\nServing on UDP :500 :4500...\nServing on UDP :9000 (WIREGUARD)...\nTCP xx.xx.xx.xx:xx -\u0026gt; HTTP xx.xx.xx.xx:xx -\u0026gt; xx.xx.xx.xx:xx\"\u003e\u003cpre\u003e$ pip3 install pvpn\nSuccessfully installed pvpn-0.2.1\n$ pvpn -wg 9999 -r http://remote_server:remote_port\nServing on UDP :500 :4500...\nServing on UDP :9000 (WIREGUARD)...\nTCP xx.xx.xx.xx:xx -\u0026gt; HTTP xx.xx.xx.xx:xx -\u0026gt; xx.xx.xx.xx:xx\u003c/pre\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003ca name=\"user-content-projects\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"markdown-heading\" dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ch2 tabindex=\"-1\" class=\"heading-element\" dir=\"auto\"\u003eProjects\u003c/h2\u003e\u003ca id=\"user-content-projects\" class=\"anchor-element\" aria-label=\"Permalink: Projects\" href=\"#projects\"\u003e\u003csvg class=\"octicon asynchronous IO.</li><li>Pure python, no additional library required.</li><li>Proxy client/server for TCP/UDP.</li><li>Schedule (load balance) among remote servers.</li><li>Incoming traffic auto-detect.</li><li>Tunnel/jump/backward-jump support.</li><li>Unix domain socket support.</li><li>HTTP v2, HTTP v3 (QUIC)</li><li>User/password authentication support.</li><li>Filter/block hostname by regex patterns.</li><li>SSL/TLS client/server support.</li><li>Shadowsocks OTA (<a href="https://shadowsocks.org/en/spec/one-time-auth.html" rel="nofollow">One-Time-Auth</a>), SSR plugins.</li><li>Statistics by bandwidth and traffic.</li><li>PAC support for javascript configuration.</li><li>Iptables/Pf NAT redirect packet tunnel.</li><li>System proxy auto-setting library to enable faster (C version) cipher. <strong>pproxy</strong> has many built-in pure python ciphers. They are lightweight and stable, but slower than C ciphers. After speedup with <a href="http://pypy.org" rel="nofollow">PyPy</a>, pure python ciphers can get similar performance as C version. If the performance is important and don't have <a href="http://pypy.org" rel="nofollow">PyPy</a>, install <a href="https://pycryptodome.readthedocs.io/en/latest/src/introduction.html" "httponly://" sends "GET/POST" as client, works only on http traffic.</li><li>Valid schemes: <a href="http://" rel="nofollow">http://</a>, http+socks4+socks5://, http+ssl://, ss+secure://, http+socks5+ss://</li><li>Invalid schemes: ssl://, secure://</li></ul></blockquote><ul dir="auto"><li><p dir="auto">cipher</p><ul dir="auto"><li><p dir="auto">Cipher's format: "cipher_name:cipher_key". Cipher can be base64-encoded. So cipher string with "YWVzLTEyOC1nY206dGVzdA==" is equal to "aes-128-gcm:test".</p></li><li><p dir="auto">Full cipher support list:</p><table><thead valign="bottom"><tr><th><p dir="auto">Cipher</p></th><th><p dir="auto">Key Length</p></th><th><p dir="auto">IV Length</p></th><th><p dir="auto">Score (0-5)</p></th></tr></thead><tbody valign="top"><tr><td><p dir="auto">table-py</p></td><td><p dir="auto">any</p></td><td><p dir="auto">0</p></td><td><p dir="auto">0 (lowest)</p></td></tr><tr><td><p dir="auto">rc4</p></td><td><p dir="auto">16</p></td><td><p dir="auto">0</p></td><td><p dir="auto">0 (lowest)</p></td></tr><tr><td><p dir="auto">rc4-md5</p></td><td><p dir="auto">16</p></td><td><p dir="auto">16</p></td><td><p dir="auto">0.5</p></td></tr><tr><td><p dir="auto">chacha20</p></td><td><p dir="auto">32</p></td><td><p dir="auto">8</p></td><td><p dir="auto">5 (highest)</p></td></tr><tr><td><p dir="auto">chacha20-ietf</p></td><td><p dir="auto">32</p></td><td><p dir="auto">12</p></td><td><p dir="auto">5</p></td></tr><tr><td><p dir="auto">chacha20-ietf-poly1305-py</p></td><td><p dir="auto">4.5</p></td></tr><tr><td><p dir="auto">aes-128-cfb</p><p dir="auto">aes-128-cfb8</p><p dir="auto">aes-128-cfb1-py</p></td><td><p dir="auto">16</p></td><td><p dir="auto">16</p></td><td><p dir="auto">16</p></td><td><p dir="auto">3.5</p><p dir="auto">slow</p></td></tr><tr><td><p dir="auto">aes-256-cfb</p><p dir="auto">aes-256-ctr</p><p dir="auto">aes-256-ofb</p><p dir="auto">aes-256-gcm</p><p dir="auto">aes-192-gcm</p><p dir="auto">aes-128-gcm</p></td><td><p dir="auto">32</p><p dir="auto">24</p><p dir="auto">16</p></td><td><p dir="auto">32</p><p dir="auto">24</p><p dir="auto">16</p></td><td><p dir="auto">AEAD</p><p dir="auto">AEAD</p><p dir="auto">AEAD</p></td></tr><tr><td><p dir="auto">camellia-256-cfb</p><p dir="auto">camellia-192-cfb</p><p dir="auto">camellia-128-cfb</p></td><td><p dir="auto">32</p><p dir="auto">24</p><p dir="auto">16</p></td><td><p dir="auto">16</p><p dir="auto">16</p><p dir="auto">16</p></td><td><p dir="auto">4</p><p dir="auto">4</p><p dir="auto">4</p></td></tr><tr><td><p dir="auto">bf-cfb</p></td><td><p dir="auto">16</p></td><td><p dir="auto">8</p></td><td><p dir="auto">1</p></td></tr><tr><td><p dir="auto">cast5-cfb</p></td><td><p dir="auto">16</p></td><td><p dir="auto">8</p></td><td><p dir="auto">2.5</p></td></tr><tr><td><p dir="auto">des-cfb</p></td><td><p dir="auto">8</p></td><td><p dir="auto">8</p></td><td><p dir="auto">1.5</p></td></tr><tr><td><p dir="auto">rc2-cfb-py</p></td><td><p dir="auto">16</p></td><td><p dir="auto">8</p></td><td><p dir="auto">2</p></td></tr><tr><td><p dir="auto">idea-cfb-py</p></td><td><p dir="auto">16</p></td><td><p dir="auto">8</p></td><td><p dir="auto">2.5</p></td></tr><tr><td><p dir="auto">seed-cfb-py</p></td><td><p dir="auto">16</p></td><td><p dir="auto">16</p></td><td><p dir="auto">2</p></td></tr></tbody></table></li><li><p dir="auto"><em>pproxy</em> ciphers have pure python implementations. Program will switch to C cipher if there is C implementation available within <a href="https://pycryptodome.readthedocs.io/en/latest/src/introduction.html" rel="nofollow">pycryptodome</a>. Otherwise, use pure python cipher.</p></li><li><p dir="auto">AEAD ciphers use additional payload after each packet. The underlying protocol is different. Specifications: <a href="http://shadowsocks.org/en/spec/AEAD-Ciphers.html" rel="nofollow">AEAD</a>.</p></li><li><p dir="auto">Some pure python ciphers (aes-256-cfb1-py) is quite slow, and is not recommended to use without PyPy speedup. Try install <a href="https://pycryptodome.readthedocs.io/en/latest/src/introduction.html" rel="nofollow">pycryptodome</a> and use C version cipher instead.</p></li><li><p dir="auto">To enable OTA encryption with shadowsocks, add '!' immediately after cipher name.</p></li></ul></li><li><p dir="auto">netloc</p><ul dir="auto"><li>It can be "hostname:port" or "/unix_domain_socket". If the hostname is empty, server will listen on all interfaces.</li><li>Valid netloc: localhost:8080, 0.0.0.0:8123, /tmp/domain_socket, :8123</li></ul></li><li><p dir="auto">localbind</p><ul dir="auto"><li>It can be "@in" or @ipv4_address or @ipv6_address</li><li>Valid localbind: @in, @192.168.1.15, @::1</li></ul></li><li><p dir="auto">plugins</p><ul dir="auto"><li>It can be multiple plugins joined by ",". Supported plugins: plain, origin, http_simple, tls1.2_ticket_auth, verify_simple, verify_deflate</li><li>Valid plugins: /,tls1.2_ticket_auth,verify_simple</li></ul></li><li><p dir="auto">rules</p><ul dir="auto"><li>The filename that contains regex rules</li></ul></li><li><p dir="auto">auth</p><ul dir="auto"><li>The username, colon ':', and the password</li></ul></li></ul><p dir="auto">URIs can be joined by "__" to indicate tunneling by jump. For example, ss://1.2.3.4:1324__<a href="http://4.5.6.7:4321" rel="nofollow">http://4.5.6.7:4321</a> make remote connection to the first shadowsocks proxy server, and then jump to the second http proxy server.</p><a name="user-content-client-api"></a><div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h2 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto">Client API</h2><a id="user-content-client-api" test_tcp(proxy_uri):    conn = pproxy.Connection(proxy_uri)    reader, writer = await conn.tcp_connect('google.com', 80)    writer.write(b'GET / HTTP/1.1\r\n\r\n')    data = await reader.read(1024*16)    print(data.decode())asyncio.run(test_tcp('ss://aes-256-cfb:password@remote_host:remote_port'))"><pre>import asyncio, pproxyasync def test_tcp(proxy_uri):    conn = pproxy.Connection(proxy_uri)    reader, writer = await conn.tcp_connect('google.com', 80)    writer.write(b'GET / HTTP/1.1<span class="pl-cce">\r\n\r\n</span>')    data = await reader.read(1024*16)    print(data.decode())asyncio.run(test_tcp('ss://aes-256-cfb:password@remote_host:remote_port'))</pre></div></li><li><p dir="auto">UDP Client API</p><div class="highlight highlight-text-restructuredtext notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="import asyncio, pproxyasync def test_udp(proxy_uri):    conn = pproxy.Connection(proxy_uri)    answer = asyncio.Future()    await conn.udp_sendto('8.8.8.8', 53, b'hello the world', answer.set_result)    await answer    print(answer.result())asyncio.run(test_udp('ss://chacha20:password@remote_host:remote_port'))"><pre>import asyncio, pproxyasync def test_udp(proxy_uri):    conn = pproxy.Connection(proxy_uri)    answer = asyncio.Future()    await conn.udp_sendto('8.8.8.8', 53, b'hello the world', answer.set_result)    await answer    print(answer.result())asyncio.run(test_udp('ss://chacha20:password@remote_host:remote_port'))</pre></div></li></ul><a name="user-content-server-api"></a><div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h2 overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="import asyncioimport pproxyserver = pproxy.Server('ss://0.0.0.0:1234')remote = pproxy.Connection('ss://1.2.3.4:5678')args = dict( rserver = [remote],             verbose = print )loop = asyncio.get_event_loop()handler = loop.run_until_complete(server.start_server(args))try:    loop.run_forever()except KeyboardInterrupt:    print('exit!')handler.close()loop.run_until_complete(handler.wait_closed())loop.run_until_complete(loop.shutdown_asyncgens())loop.close()"><pre>import asyncioimport pproxyserver = pproxy.Server('ss://0.0.0.0:1234')remote = pproxy.Connection('ss://1.2.3.4:5678')args = dict( rserver = [remote],             verbose = print )loop = asyncio.get_event_loop()handler = href="#examples"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div><ul dir="auto"><li><p dir="auto">Regex rule</p><p dir="auto">Define regex file "rules" as follow:</p><div class="highlight highlight-text-restructuredtext notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="#google domains(?:.+\.)?google.*\.com(?:.+\.)?gstatic\.com(?:.+\.)?gmail\.com(?:.+\.)?ntp\.org(?:.+\.)?glpals\.com(?:.+\.)?akamai.*\.net(?:.+\.)?ggpht\.com(?:.+\.)?android\.com(?:.+\.)?gvt1\.com(?:.+\.)?youtube.*\.com(?:.+\.)?ytimg\.com(?:.+\.)?goo\.gl(?:.+\.)?youtu\.be(?:.+\.)?google\..+"><pre>#google domains(?:.+<span class="pl-cce">\.</span>)?google.*<span class="pl-cce">\.</span>com(?:.+<span class="pl-cce">\.</span>)?gstatic<span class="pl-cce">\.</span>com(?:.+<span class="pl-cce">\.</span>)?gmail<span class="pl-cce">\.</span>com(?:.+<span class="pl-cce">\.</span>)?ntp<span class="pl-cce">\.</span>org(?:.+<span class="pl-cce">\.</span>)?glpals<span class="pl-cce">\.</span>com(?:.+<span class="pl-cce">\.</span>)?akamai.*<span class="pl-cce">\.</span>net(?:.+<span class="pl-cce">\.</span>)?ggpht<span class="pl-cce">\.</span>com(?:.+<span class="pl-cce">\.</span>)?android<span class="pl-cce">\.</span>com(?:.+<span class="pl-cce">\.</span>)?gvt1<span class="pl-cce">\.</span>com(?:.+<span class="pl-cce">\.</span>)?youtube.*<span class="pl-cce">\.</span>com(?:.+<span class="pl-cce">\.</span>)?ytimg<span class="pl-cce">\.</span>com(?:.+<span class="pl-cce">\.</span>)?goo<span class="pl-cce">\.</span>gl(?:.+<span class="pl-cce">\.</span>)?youtu<span class="pl-cce">\.</span>be(?:.+<span class="pl-cce">\.</span>)?google<span class="pl-cce">\.</span>.+</pre></div><p dir="auto">Then start <em>pproxy</em></p><div class="highlight highlight-text-restructuredtext notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="$ pproxy -r http://aa.bb.cc.dd:8080?rules -vvServing on :8080 by http,socks4,socks5http ::1:57768 -> http aa.bb.cc.dd:8080 -> www.googleapis.com:443http ::1:57772 -> www.yahoo.com:80socks4 ::1:57770 -> http aa.bb.cc.dd:8080 -> www.youtube.com:443"><pre>$ pproxy -r http://aa.bb.cc.dd:8080?rules -vvServing on :8080 by http,socks4,socks5http ::1:57768 -> http aa.bb.cc.dd:8080 -> www.googleapis.com:443http ::1:57772 -> www.yahoo.com:80socks4 ::1:57770 -> http aa.bb.cc.dd:8080 -> www.youtube.com:443</pre></div><p dir="auto"><em>pproxy</em> will serve incoming traffic by http/socks4/socks5 auto-detect protocol, redirect all google traffic to http proxy aa.bb.cc.dd:8080, and visit all other traffic directly from local.</p></li><li><p dir="auto">Use cipher</p><p dir="auto">Add cipher encryption to make sure data can't be intercepted. Run <em>pproxy</em> locally as:</p><div class="highlight highlight-text-restructuredtext notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="$ pproxy -l ss://:8888 -r ss://chacha20:cipher_key@aa.bb.cc.dd:12345 -vv"><pre>$ pproxy -l ss://:8888 -r ss://chacha20:cipher_key@aa.bb.cc.dd:12345 -vv</pre></div><p dir="auto">Next, run pproxy.py remotely on server "aa.bb.cc.dd". The base64 encoded string of "chacha20:cipher_key" is also supported:</p><div class="highlight highlight-text-restructuredtext notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="$ pproxy -l ss://chacha20:cipher_key@:12345"><pre>$ pproxy -l ss://chacha20:cipher_key@:12345</pre></div><p dir="auto">The same as:</p><div class="highlight highlight-text-restructuredtext notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="$ pproxy -l ss://Y2hhY2hhMjA6Y2lwaGVyX2tleQ==@:12345"><pre>$ pproxy -l ss://Y2hhY2hhMjA6Y2lwaGVyX2tleQ==@:12345</pre></div><p dir="auto">The traffic between local and aa.bb.cc.dd is encrypted by stream cipher Chacha20 with secret key "cipher_key".</p></li><li><p dir="auto">Unix domain socket</p><p dir="auto">A more complex example:</p><div class="highlight highlight-text-restructuredtext notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="$ pproxy -l ss://salsa20!:complex_cipher_key@/tmp/pproxy_socket -r http+ssl://domain1.com:443#username:password"><pre>$ pproxy -l ss://salsa20!:complex_cipher_key@/tmp/pproxy_socket -r http+ssl://domain1.com:443#username:password</pre></div><p dir="auto"><em>pproxy</em> listen on the unix domain socket "/tmp/pproxy_socket" with cipher "salsa20" and key "complex_cipher_key". OTA packet protocol is enabled by adding ! after cipher name. The traffic is tunneled to remote https proxy with simple http authentication.</p></li><li><p dir="auto">SSL/TLS server</p><p dir="auto">If you want to listen in SSL/TLS, you must specify ssl certificate and private key files by parameter "--ssl":</p><div class="highlight highlight-text-restructuredtext notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="$ pproxy -l http+ssl://0.0.0.0:443 -l http://0.0.0.0:80 --ssl server.crt,server.key --pac /autopac"><pre>$ pproxy -l http+ssl://0.0.0.0:443 -l http://0.0.0.0:80 --ssl server.crt,server.key --pac /autopac</pre></div><p dir="auto"><em>pproxy</em> listen on both 80 HTTP and 443 HTTPS ports, use the specified SSL/TLS certificate and private key files. The "--pac" enable PAC feature, so you can put "<a href="https://yourdomain.com/autopac" rel="nofollow">https://yourdomain.com/autopac</a>" path in your device's auto-configure url.</p><p dir="auto">Simple guide for generating self-signed ssl certificates:</p><div class="highlight highlight-text-restructuredtext notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="$ openssl genrsa -des3 -out server.key 1024$ openssl req -new -key server.key -out server.csr$ cp server.key server.key.org$ openssl rsa -in server.key.org -out server.key$ openssl x509 -req -days 365 -in server.csr -signkey server.key -out server.crt"><pre>$ openssl genrsa -des3 -out server.key 1024$ openssl req -new -key server.key -out server.csr$ cp server.key server.key.org$ openssl rsa -in server.key.org -out server.key$ openssl x509 -req -days 365 -in server.csr -signkey server.key -out server.crt</pre></div></li><li><p dir="auto">SSR plugins</p><p dir="auto">ShadowsocksR example with plugin "tls1.2_ticket_auth" to emulate common tls traffic:</p><div class="highlight highlight-text-restructuredtext notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="$ pproxy -l ssr://chacha20:mypass@0.0.0.0:443/,tls1.2_ticket_auth,verify_simple"><pre>$ pproxy -l ssr://chacha20:mypass@0.0.0.0:443/,tls1.2_ticket_auth,verify_simple</pre></div></li><li><p dir="auto">Local bind ip</p><p dir="auto">If you want to route the traffic by different local bind, use the @localbind URI syntax. For example, server has three ip interfaces: 192.168.1.15, 111.0.0.1, 112.0.0.1. You want to route traffic matched by "rule1" to 111.0.0.2 and traffic matched by "rule2" to 222.0.0.2, and the remaining traffic directly:</p><div class="highlight highlight-text-restructuredtext notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="$ pproxy -l ss://:8000/@in -r ss://111.0.0.2:8000/@111.0.0.1?rule1 -r ss://222.0.0.2:8000/@222.0.0.1?rule2"><pre>$ pproxy -l ss://:8000/@in -r ss://111.0.0.2:8000/@111.0.0.1?rule1 -r ss://222.0.0.2:8000/@222.0.0.1?rule2</pre></div></li><li><p dir="auto">Redirect/Pf protocol</p><p dir="auto">IPTable NAT redirect example (Ubuntu):</p><div class="highlight highlight-text-restructuredtext notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="$ sudo iptables -t nat -A OUTPUT -p tcp --dport 80 -j REDIRECT --to-ports 5555$ pproxy -l redir://:5555 -r http://remote_http_server:3128 -vv"><pre>$ sudo iptables -t nat -A OUTPUT -p tcp --dport 80 -j REDIRECT --to-ports 5555$ pproxy -l redir://:5555 -r http://remote_http_server:3128 -vv</pre></div><p dir="auto">The above example illustrates how to redirect all local output tcp traffic with destination port 80 to localhost port 5555 listened by <strong>pproxy</strong>, and then tunnel the traffic to remote http proxy.</p><p dir="auto">PF redirect example (MacOS):</p><div class="highlight highlight-text-restructuredtext notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="$ sudo pfctl -ef /dev/stdinrdr pass on lo0 inet proto tcp from any to any port 80 -> 127.0.0.1 port 8080pass out on en0 route-to lo0 inet proto tcp from any to any port 80 keep state^D$ sudo pproxy -l pf://:8080 -r socks5://remote_socks5_server:1324 -vv"><pre>$ sudo pfctl -ef /dev/stdinrdr pass on lo0 inet proto tcp from any to any port 80 -> 127.0.0.1 port 8080pass out on en0 route-to lo0 inet proto tcp from any to any port 80 keep state^D$ sudo pproxy -l pf://:8080 -r socks5://remote_socks5_server:1324 -vv</pre></div><p dir="auto">Make sure <strong>pproxy</strong> runs in root mode (sudo), otherwise it cannot redirect pf packet.</p></li><li><p dir="auto">Multiple jumps example</p><div class="highlight highlight-text-restructuredtext notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="$ pproxy -r http://server1__ss://server2__socks://server3"><pre>$ pproxy -r http://server1__ss://server2__socks://server3</pre></div><p dir="auto"><em>pproxy</em> will connect to server1 first, tell server1 connect to server2, and tell server2 connect to server3, and make real traffic by server3.</p></li><li><p dir="auto">Raw connection tunnel</p><p dir="auto">TCP raw connection tunnel example:</p><div class="highlight highlight-text-restructuredtext notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="$ pproxy -l tunnel{google.com}://:80$ curl -H "Host: google.com" http://localhost"><pre>$ pproxy -l tunnel{google.com}://:80$ curl -H "Host: google.com" http://localhost</pre></div><p dir="auto">UDP dns tunnel example:</p><div class="highlight highlight-text-restructuredtext notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="$ pproxy -ul tunnel{8.8.8.8}://:53$ nslookup google.com localhost"><pre>$ pproxy -ul tunnel{8.8.8.8}://:53$ nslookup google.com localhost</pre></div></li><li><p dir="auto">UDP more complicated example</p><p dir="auto">Run the shadowsocks udp proxy on remote machine:</p><div class="highlight highlight-text-restructuredtext notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="$ pproxy -ul ss://remote_server:13245"><pre>$ pproxy -ul ss://remote_server:13245</pre></div><p dir="auto">Run the commands on local machine:</p><div class="highlight highlight-text-restructuredtext notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="$ pproxy -ul tunnel{8.8.8.8}://:53 -ur ss://remote_server:13245 -vvUDP tunnel 127.0.0.1:60573 -> ss remote_server:13245 -> 8.8.8.8:53UDP tunnel 127.0.0.1:60574 -> ss remote_server:13245 -> 8.8.8.8:53...$ nslookup google.com localhost"><pre>$ pproxy -ul tunnel{8.8.8.8}://:53 -ur ss://remote_server:13245 -vvUDP tunnel 127.0.0.1:60573 -> ss remote_server:13245 -> 8.8.8.8:53UDP tunnel 127.0.0.1:60574 -> ss remote_server:13245 -> 8.8.8.8:53<span class="pl-mh">...</span>$ nslookup google.com localhost</pre></div></li><li><p dir="auto">Load balance example</p><p dir="auto">Specify multiple -r server, and a scheduling algorithm (rr = round_robin, rc = random_choice, lc = least_connection):</p><div class="highlight highlight-text-restructuredtext notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="$ pproxy -r http://server1 -r ss://server2 -r socks5://server3 -s rr -vvhttp ::1:42356 -> http server1 -> google.com:443http ::1:42357 -> ss server2 -> google.com:443http ::1:42358 -> socks5 server3 -> google.com:443http ::1:42359 -> http server1 -> google.com:443...$ pproxy -ul tunnel://:53 -ur tunnel://8.8.8.8:53 -ur tunnel://8.8.4.4:53 -s rc -vvUDP tunnel ::1:35378 -> tunnel 8.8.8.8:53UDP tunnel ::1:35378 -> tunnel 8.8.4.4:53..."><pre>$ pproxy -r http://server1 -r ss://server2 -r socks5://server3 -s rr -vvhttp ::1:42356 -> http server1 -> google.com:443http ::1:42357 -> ss server2 -> google.com:443http ::1:42358 -> socks5 server3 -> google.com:443http ::1:42359 -> http server1 -> google.com:443<span class="pl-mh">...</span>$ pproxy -ul tunnel://:53 -ur tunnel://8.8.8.8:53 -ur tunnel://8.8.4.4:53 -s rc -vvUDP tunnel ::1:35378 -> tunnel 8.8.8.8:53UDP tunnel ::1:35378 -> tunnel 8.8.4.4:53<span class="pl-mh">...</span></pre></div></li><li><p dir="auto">WebSocket example</p><p dir="auto">WebSocket protocol is similar to Tunnel protocol. It is raw and doesn't support any proxy function. It can connect to other proxy like Tunnel protocol.</p><p dir="auto">First run pproxy on remote machine:</p><div class="highlight highlight-text-restructuredtext notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="$ pproxy -l ws://:80 -r tunnel:///tmp/myproxy -v$ pproxy -l ss://chacha20:abc@/tmp/myproxy -v"><pre>$ pproxy -l ws://:80 -r tunnel:///tmp/myproxy -v$ pproxy -l ss://chacha20:abc@/tmp/myproxy -v</pre></div><p dir="auto">Run pproxy on local machine:</p><div class="highlight highlight-text-restructuredtext notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="$ pproxy -l tunnel://:1234 -r ws://remote_ip:80 -vv"><pre>$ pproxy -l tunnel://:1234 -r ws://remote_ip:80 -vv</pre></div><p dir="auto">Then port :1234 on local machine is connected to the /tmp/myproxy on remote machine by WebSocket tunnel. You can specify any proxy protocol details on /tmp/myproxy.</p><p dir="auto">It is a good practice to use some CDN in the middle of local/remote machines. CDN with WebSocket support can hide remote machine's real IP from public.</p></li><li><p dir="auto">Backward proxy</p><p dir="auto">Sometimes, the proxy server hides behind an NAT router and doesn't have a public ip. The client side has a public ip "client_ip". Backward proxy feature enables the server to connect backward to client and wait for proxy requests.</p><p dir="auto">Run <strong>pproxy</strong> client as follows:</p><div class="highlight highlight-text-restructuredtext notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="$ pproxy -l http://:8080 -r http+in://:8081 -v"><pre>$ pproxy -l http://:8080 -r http+in://:8081 -v</pre></div><p dir="auto">Run <strong>pproxy</strong> server as follows:</p><div class="highlight highlight-text-restructuredtext notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="$ pproxy -l http+in://client_ip:8081"><pre>$ pproxy -l http+in://client_ip:8081</pre></div><p dir="auto">Server connects to client_ip:8081 and waits for client proxy requests. The protocol http specified is just an example. It can be any protocol and cipher <strong>pproxy</strong> supports. The scheme "<strong>in</strong>" should exist in URI to inform <strong>pproxy</strong> that it is a backward proxy.</p><div class="highlight highlight-text-restructuredtext notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="$ pproxy -l http+in://jumpserver__http://client_ip:8081"><pre>$ pproxy -l http+in://jumpserver__http://client_ip:8081</pre></div><p dir="auto">It is a complicated example. Server connects to client_ip:8081 by jump <a href="http://jumpserver" rel="nofollow">http://jumpserver</a>. The backward proxy works through jumps.</p></li><li><p dir="auto">SSH client tunnel</p><p dir="auto">SSH client tunnel support is enabled by installing additional library <a href="https://asyncssh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/" rel="nofollow">asyncssh</a>. After "pip3 install asyncssh", you can specify "<strong>ssh</strong>" as scheme to proxy via ssh client tunnel.</p><div class="highlight highlight-text-restructuredtext notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="$ pproxy -l http://:8080 -r ssh://remote_server.com/#login:password"><pre>$ pproxy -l http://:8080 -r ssh://remote_server.com/#login:password</pre></div><p dir="auto">If a client private key is used to authenticate, put double colon "::" between login and private key path.</p><div class="highlight highlight-text-restructuredtext notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="$ pproxy -l http://:8080 -r ssh://remote_server.com/#login::private_key_path"><pre>$ pproxy -l http://:8080 -r ssh://remote_server.com/#login::private_key_path</pre></div><p dir="auto">SSH connection known_hosts feature is disabled by default.</p></li><li><p dir="auto">SSH jump</p><p dir="auto">SSH jump is supported by using "__" concatenation</p><div class="highlight highlight-text-restructuredtext notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="$ pproxy -r ssh://server1__ssh://server2__ssh://server3"><pre>$ pproxy -r ssh://server1__ssh://server2__ssh://server3</pre></div><p dir="auto">First connection to server1 is made. Second, ssh connection to server2 is made from server1. Finally, connect to server3, and use server3 for proxying traffic.</p></li><li><p dir="auto">SSH remote forward</p><div class="highlight highlight-text-restructuredtext notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="$ pproxy -l ssh://server__tunnel://0.0.0.0:1234 -r tunnel://127.0.0.1:1234"><pre>$ pproxy -l ssh://server__tunnel://0.0.0.0:1234 -r tunnel://127.0.0.1:1234</pre></div><p dir="auto">TCP :1234 on remote server is forwarded to 127.0.0.1:1234 on local server</p><div class="highlight highlight-text-restructuredtext notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="$ pproxy -l ssh://server1__ssh://server2__ss://0.0.0.0:1234 -r ss://server3:1234"><pre>$ pproxy -l ssh://server1__ssh://server2__ss://0.0.0.0:1234 -r ss://server3:1234</pre></div><p dir="auto">It is a complicated example. SSH server2 is jumped from SSH server1, and ss://0.0.0.0:1234 on server2 is listened. Traffic is forwarded to ss://server3:1234.</p></li><li><p dir="auto">Trojan protocol example</p><p dir="auto">Normally trojan:// should be used together with ssl://. You should specify the SSL crt/key file for ssl usage. A typical trojan server would be:</p><div class="highlight highlight-text-restructuredtext notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="$ pproxy --ssl ssl.crt,ssl.key -l trojan+tunnel{localhost:80}+ssl://:443#yourpassword -vv"><pre>$ pproxy --ssl ssl.crt,ssl.key -l trojan+tunnel{localhost:80}+ssl://:443#yourpassword -vv</pre></div><p dir="auto">If trojan password doesn't match, the tunnal{localhost:80} will be switched to. It looks exactly the same as a common HTTPS website.</p></li><li><p dir="auto">QUIC protocol example</p><p dir="auto">QUIC is a UDP stream protocol used in HTTP/3. Library <strong>aioquic</strong> is required if you want to proxy via QUIC.QUIC is listened on UDP port, but can handle TCP or UDP traffic. If you want to handle TCP traffic, you should use "-l quic+http" instead of "-ul quic+http".</p><div class="highlight highlight-text-restructuredtext notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="$ pip3 install aioquic$ pproxy --ssl ssl.crt,ssl.key -l quic+http://:1234"><pre>$ pip3 install aioquic$ pproxy --ssl ssl.crt,ssl.key -l quic+http://:1234</pre></div><p dir="auto">On the client:</p><blockquote><p dir="auto">$ pproxy -r quic+http://server:1234</p></blockquote><p dir="auto">QUIC protocol can transfer a lot of TCP streams on one single UDP stream. If the connection number is hugh, QUIC can benefit by reducing TCP handshake time.</p></li><li><p dir="auto">VPN Server Example</p><p dir="auto">You can run VPN server simply by installing pvpn (python vpn), a lightweight VPN server with pproxy tunnel feature.</p><div class="highlight highlight-text-restructuredtext notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="$ pip3 install pvpnSuccessfully installed pvpn-0.2.1$ pvpn -wg 9999 -r http://remote_server:remote_portServing on UDP :500 :4500...Serving on UDP :9000 (WIREGUARD)...TCP xx.xx.xx.xx:xx -> HTTP xx.xx.xx.xx:xx -> xx.xx.xx.xx:xx"><pre>$ pip3 install pvpnSuccessfully installed pvpn-0.2.1$ pvpn -wg 9999 -r http://remote_server:remote_portServing on UDP :500 :4500...Serving on UDP :9000 (WIREGUARD)...TCP xx.xx.xx.xx:xx -> HTTP xx.xx.xx.xx:xx -> xx.xx.xx.xx:xx</pre></div></li></ul><a name="user-content-projects"></a><div class="markdown-heading"
